text: why formik not supporting? please help me

Hi everyone! I'm currently trying to implement a new pricing calculator, actually it's a complex pricing calculator and I was thinking of implementing it using react. Do you guys think it's a good idea to use the react feature in HubSpot now?
how do i find the content_group_id for my blogs?
Hi just wanting to double check, we absolutely can't add dnd sections to a blog_listing template? if theres a workaround pls share thanks
Is there a reason why I am seeing a forever spinner icon when trying to add content into my module
You can also use URL query params (set by a React component) and send them to a GraphQL query via a serverless function.

Hi, I’ve built two calculators using React, nothing too complicated, but everything works fine. If you want to get into this new “cms-js-rendering” path, it’s a good place to start. Especially if it’s touching on all the other related tech stacks like HubDB, serverless functions, and GraphQL.

One thing to note: define what you need to accomplish and how and make sure there are no limitations in the way — CMS JS Rendering does have a few limitations, especially in the way it fetches data.

Will check it out, from your error screenshot I’d guess that somewhere in the code is accessing `process` from node, but that doesn’t work in a browser context.  I wonder if formik’s server rendering support isn’t great :thinking_face: … :soon:

You can add D&D areas to blog listing templates, but not _blog post_ templates:

<https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/blog/edit-a-blog-listing-page>
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/hubl/tags/dnd-areas>

Though please, our team doesn’t have the bandwidth to do HubSpot support outside of the context of React modules & partials. So we’d really appreciate it to keep your non-React-related questions and support requests elsewhere :pray: :thanku:
Repeating <https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/archives/C04AY1H2204/p1706796450311599?thread_ts=1706788047.568509&cid=C04AY1H2204> here (not even sure if this is a react module?)

Hi, everyone! My team has been migrating our project to React, but we're at a point where we have some published pages that are using templates that still have modules from the old HubL project. We'd like to change that by migrating all modules to React and are looking for reassurance that we won't break already published pages.

I ran some tests on my personal sandbox where I published a page based on a template with an "old" HubL module, then modified the template to use a React module with the same exact fields as the old one, updated those changes, and the already published pages seem to be able to pick up the change and still pass the same field values to the new module as they did to the old one.

Can someone confirm that this is, in fact, expected behavior and not just a fluke? Thank you!

I’m not seeing anything obvious from searching around formik’s docs and source. We’ll need more context, like portal id, project name, build/deploy #, to help debug (can DM to me or <@UAYBXDG4U> if you’d rather not share that directly here)

Yes, that is expected behavior. In fact, we’ve done things like that internally where we copied the `field.json` of the previous module (and used that directly (to start) for the React module port to know for sure that the field structure is the same.

```export const fields = fieldsJson;
import fieldsJson from './fields.json'```
Some other suggestions to gain confidence & validate…

You can make your template changes (swap to React module) and preview that before publishing the template.

You could temporarily make the template using something on `request` (like a URL param) change between using the HubL module and React module. And then you could use that dedicated debugging param to check things live before removing that conditional and fully swapping over.

(Though note, don’t keep request-based logic in your template if not needed. Since it prevents prerendering caching that can significantly improves performance)

If something like this was a common case, makes me wonder if we could/should have a local development proxy query param or setting that enables you to say, “Hey for all instances of module X please replace with my local module Y”

Hi everyone,

Are there any news / updated recommendations on how to handle staging environments?
A bit similar to what Maria is saying there with the personal sandbox.

I have a separate CMS account but it still won't show me the "CRM development" options for staging. I though about having a separate theme folder in the design manager and use content staging features.

Is that a good approach?

Any thoughts here are appreciated :slightly_smiling_face:
Thank you for your answer! Will look into those suggestions as well.

> I have a separate CMS account but it still won't show me the "CRM development" options for staging.
What are you using within "CRM development" in this scenario?

The developer projects to upload React modules and partials to.
Without that, I'm not able to preview the full theme.
You should be able to navigate directly to the `developer-projects` url for any portal with CMS.
and/or click directly on the link in the CLI output when running `hs project upload`
Also you don't need to create the project within the UI before first upload.
You can just upload a valid project structure and the CLI will ask you if you want to create project ... then when you upload you will get the link in the CLI

good to know, thank you!

i knew i was missing something here :slightly_smiling_face:
i'll try it in a few minutes
you’re right though it is still a problem to not be able to navigate to it in the nav, we are hoping to long term make it available there and maybe a more accurate name as well
The above worked perfectly, finally fixed something that was bugging me for a while, thank you!

Another question.

Since the dev server wraps around Storybook, how do I create my own static build of Storybook? I would like to publish our Storybook to <http://chromatic.com|Chromatic> so I can link it with Figma which is where we're designing things.

Running the `npx chromatic --project-token=[token]` command obviously doesn't do anything because there is no build script. It would be good to have some level of control of Storybook.
This is a great suggestion and something that we have talked about internally. I can't promise anything here but your feedback is well taken.

Also, not having any kind of search functionality on the documentation makes it really hard to find things.
Are you planning to add search to <https://github.HubSpot.com/cms-js-building-block-examples/>?

Searching via Google isn't very helpful. I'd still much prefer to have this documentation in the standard HubSpot docs as previously shared, but I understand that others might like it this way :slightly_smiling_face:

Also the pricing calculator we are planning to create has some quite complex functionalities on how the data is being calculated and I think react is a great choice implementing this one. Will definitely check it out. Thanks!
